title.text: An Earley Parsing Algorithm for Range Concatenation Grammars

abstractContent.text: We present a CYK and an Earley-style algorithm for parsing Range Concatena-tion Grammar (RCG), using the deduc-tive parsing framework.
The characteristic property of the Earley parser is that we use a technique of range boundary constraint propagation to compute the yields of non-terminals as late as possible.
Experiments show that, compared to previous approaches, the constraint propagation helps to considerably decrease the number of items in the chart.

introductionContent.text: RCGs) have recently received a growing interest in natural language processing.
RCGs generate exactly the class of languages parsable in deterministic polynomial time).
They are in particular more powerful than linear context-free rewriting systems (LCFRS).
LCFRS is unable to describe certain natural language phenomena that RCGs actually can deal with.
One example are long-distance scrambling phenomena ().
Other examples are non-semilinear constructions such as case stacking in Old Georgian ( and Chinese number names.
shows that RCGs can describe the permutations occurring with scrambling and the construction of Chinese number names.
Parsing algorithms for RCG have been introduced by, who presents a directional top-down parsing algorithm using pseudocode, and, who add an oracle to Boullier's algorithm.
The more restricted class of LCFRS has received more attention concerning parsing (Villemonte de la).
This article proposes new CYK and Earley parsers for RCG, formulating them in the framework of parsing as deduction (.
The second section introduces necessary definitions.
Section 3 presents a CYK-style algorithm and Section 4 extends this with an Earley-style prediction.
